com.intel.util

Class LanguageUtil

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.intel.util.LanguageUtil

  • @ThreadSafe
public final class LanguageUtil
extends java.lang.Object
    Utility class to deal with app language.

    • Field Detail

      • ACTION_LANGUAGE_CHANGED

        @NonNull
public static final java.lang.String ACTION_LANGUAGE_CHANGED
        Broadcast action for notifying a language change.

    • Method Detail

      • applyUserLanguage

        public static void applyUserLanguage(@NonNull
                                     android.content.Context appContext,
                                     @NonNull
                                     java.lang.String userLocale,
                                     boolean broadcastChanges)
        Applies user-selected language to the app by overriding the app locale. Once this is called, any subsequent calls to Locale.getDefault() will return the new language. More importantly, any access to string resources will also be resolved accordingly.

        Once the locale is changed, a broadcast can be triggered for ACTION_LANGUAGE_CHANGED, so listeners can perform any action needed after a language change.

        When the system language and the user-selected language already match, this method will simply use the system locale as the user-selected locale.
        Parameters:
        appContext - Application context.
        userLocale - User-selected locale to apply, in the format language_COUNTRY (e.g. en_US).
        broadcastChanges - Whether or not a broadcast should be triggered after locale is changed.

      • fromLocaleString

        @NonNull
public static java.util.Locale fromLocaleString(@NonNull
                                                         java.lang.String localeString)
        Generates a Locale instance from a string representing a locale. IMPORTANT: Note that this method is not meant to enable interoperability between actual Locale instances and their serialized counterparts. For that purpose, Locale.forLanguageTag(String) and Locale.toLanguageTag() should be used. This is to convert application-defined locales that use underscore "_" to split languages and countries as follows: en_US, de_DE, fr_FR and so on.
        Parameters:
        localeString - The string to be converted to a Locale.
        Returns:
        The corresponding locale for the given localeString.

      • getUserLocale

        @NonNull
public static java.util.Locale getUserLocale(@NonNull
                                                      android.content.Context appContext)
        Gets the current user-selected locale stored in preferences.

        If applyUserLanguage(Context, String, boolean) was called before, this will resolve to the same locale as calling Locale.getDefault(). If no value was set before, getSystemLocale() will be returned instead.
        Parameters:
        appContext - Application context.
        Returns:
        Locale selected by the user.

      • getSystemLocale

        @NonNull
public static java.util.Locale getSystemLocale()
        Returns a cached system locale. This can be trusted to be the same locale set in the phone's settings, before we override it in the app with one of the supported languages. Use it whenever you need the real device locale, untouched by the app.
        Returns:
        Cached system locale.

      • cacheSystemLocale

        public static void cacheSystemLocale()
        Caches the system locale, to be later retrieved with getSystemLocale(). Be sure to only call this before applyUserLanguage(Context, String, boolean) in the application's lifecycle, to make sure an unchanged locale is cached.
